title: Color vision
authors: Gegenfurtner, K. R. & Kiper, D. C.
summary: This paper reviews the neural mechanisms underlying color perception in humans. It describes how the retina encodes color information using three types of cones (S, M, L) sensitive to different wavelengths. In the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and visual cortex, signals are combined in opponent channels (red-green, blue-yellow, luminance) that construct color perception. It emphasizes that color perception is a distributed process, dependent on integration with shape, motion, and luminance.
keywords: color, perception, retina, LGN, opponent channels, visual cortex, hues, luminance, visual processing, shape-color integration

title: A direct demonstration of functional specialization in human visual cortex
summary: This study demonstrates that the human visual cortex is organized into functionally specialized areas for processing different visual attributes, such as color, shape, and motion. Using neuroimaging techniques, Zeki shows that area V4 is primarily involved in color processing, while area V5 (MT) responds selectively to motion. These findings support the idea that visual perception emerges from the coordinated integration of multiple specialized modules.
keywords: visual cortex, functional specialization, V4 area, V5 area, color processing, motion processing, neuroimaging, visual perception, specialized modules

title: Three cortical stages of colour processing in the human brain
summary: This paper describes three cortical stages in color processing in the human brain. The first occurs in area V1, where neurons respond to simple color contrasts. The second stage, in area V2, integrates signals of different wavelengths. Finally, the third stage, in area V4, represents stable and conscious color perception, independent of illumination. The work demonstrates that the experience of color is the result of a hierarchy of progressive processing through the visual cortex.
keywords: color processing, visual cortex, area V1, area V2, area V4, color perception, cortical hierarchy, color integration, visual experience

title: The architecture of the colour centre in the human visual cortex
summary: This study analyzes the functional organization of area V4, considered the “color center” in the human visual cortex. Using fMRI, the authors show that V4 is not a single region, but a distributed set of subregions that respond selectively to different aspects of color, such as saturation, contrast, and color constancy. The results support the idea of a distributed cortical network dedicated to color processing, rather than a single module.
keywords: V4 area, color center, visual cortex, fMRI, color processing, functional organization, subregions, saturation, contrast, color constancy

title: Categorical encoding of color in the brain
summary: This study investigates how the brain encodes colors into perceptual categories. Using fMRI, the authors found that regions of the occipital and temporal cortex respond differently to colors belonging to different linguistic categories, even when the physical differences are minimal. This suggests that color encoding depends not only on sensory perception, but also on cognitive and linguistic factors, demonstrating an interaction between visual perception and conceptual representation
keywords: color encoding, perceptual categories, fMRI, occipital cortex, temporal cortex, sensory perception, cognitive factors, language, perception-concept interaction

title: The response to colour in the human visual cortex: an fMRI review
summary: This review analyzes fMRI studies on how different areas of the human visual cortex respond to color stimuli. It confirms that areas V1, V2, and V4 show specific responses to color information, with V4 playing a central role in conscious color perception. The article also highlights the interaction between color, luminance, and attention, and how these variables modulate cortical activation. Mullen proposes a hierarchical model where color perception emerges from a distributed network that integrates spatial and chromatic information
keywords: fMRI, visual cortex, areas V1, V2, V4, color perception, luminance, attention, cortical activation, hierarchical model, distributed network

title: Human V4 activity patterns predict behavioral performance
summary: This study shows that neural activity in the V4 area of the human brain predicts performance on color-related perceptual tasks. Using fMRI and multivoxel analysis, the authors demonstrated that activation patterns in V4 contain sufficient information to distinguish perceived colors, even when physical differences in stimuli are small. This suggests that V4 not only passively encodes color, but also reflects the perceptual experience and behavioral performance associated with color
keywords: V4 area, perceptual performance, fMRI, multivoxel analysis, color encoding, perceptual experience, behavioral performance, neural activation

title: Exploring the effect of red and blue on cognitive task performance
summary: This study analyzes how the colors red and blue influence cognitive performance. The results show that the color red tends to improve attention to detail and performance in precision tasks, while blue promotes creativity and abstract thinking. At the neurophysiological level, differences in cortical activation related to emotional modulation and cognitive load are observed. These findings support the idea that colors can systematically modulate mental states and executive functions
keywords: colors, cognitive performance, attention, creativity, cortical activation, emotional modulation, cognitive load, executive functions, red color, blue color

title: The processing of color preference in the brain
summary: This study investigates how the brain processes color preferences and which neural areas are involved. Using fMRI, the authors identified greater activation in regions of the visual cortex (V4) and areas associated with the reward system, such as the ventral striatum, when participants viewed colors they reported as preferred. The results suggest that color preference integrates both visual perception and affective processes, connecting visual aesthetics with motivation and pleasure
keywords: color preference, fMRI, visual cortex, V4 area, reward system, ventral striatum, visual perception, affective processes, visual aesthetics, motivation

title: Toward a unified theory of visual area V4
summary: This paper proposes a unified theory on the function of the V4 visual area, integrating findings on color, shape, and attention. The authors review neurophysiological and neuroimaging evidence indicating that V4 is not only specialized in color processing, but also participates in the encoding of shape, texture, and spatial organization of visual stimuli. It is proposed that V4 acts as an integrative center that combines chromatic and geometric information, facilitating the coherent perception of objects
keywords: V4 area, unified theory, color processing, shape coding, texture, spatial organization, information integration, object perception, neurophysiology, neuroimaging

title: Representation of perceived object shape by the human lateral occipital complex
summary: This study demonstrates that the lateral occipital complex (LOC) of the human brain represents the perceived shape of objects, rather than their simple physical characteristics. Using fMRI, the authors observed that activity in the LOC remains stable even when visual aspects such as texture, color, or lighting change, as long as the perceived shape of the object remains the same. This suggests that the LOC plays a crucial role in the abstraction and recognition of shapes, independent of superficial sensory information
keywords: lateral occipital complex, LOC, perceived shape, fMRI, object recognition, shape abstraction, sensory independence, visual perception

title: The lateral occipital complex and its role in object recognition
authors: Grill-Spector, K., Kourtzi, Z. & Kanwisher, N.
summary: This study delves into the role of the lateral occipital complex (LOC) in object recognition. Using fMRI, it was observed that the LOC responds strongly to the perception of complete objects compared to their fragmented parts or stimuli without a coherent shape. Furthermore, its activation is associated with conscious identification of objects rather than simple visual detection. These results consolidate the LOC as a key region in the visual hierarchy for shape and object recognition
keywords: lateral occipital complex, LOC, object recognition, fMRI, visual perception, conscious identification, visual hierarchy, coherent forms

title: Shape perception reduces activity in human primary visual cortex
summary: This study reveals that coherent perception of form reduces activity in the primary visual cortex (V1). Using fMRI, the authors demonstrated that when observers perceive an organized figure from ambiguous visual stimuli, activity in V1 decreases, while it increases in higher regions such as the lateral occipital complex (LOC). These results suggest that shape perception involves hierarchical processing with feedback from higher areas, which optimizes the efficiency of visual processing
keywords: shape perception, primary visual cortex, V1, fMRI, lateral occipital complex, LOC, hierarchical processing, feedback, visual efficiency

title: The large-scale organization of shape processing in visual cortex
summary: This study explores the large-scale organization of shape processing in the human visual cortex. Using fMRI and functional connectivity analysis, the authors show that shape processing is not limited to a single region (such as the LOC), but involves a distributed network that includes ventral and dorsal areas. Functional gradients representing different levels of form abstraction, from local features to global representations of objects, are identified. This suggests a highly integrated and hierarchical visual architecture
keywords: shape processing, visual cortex, fMRI, functional connectivity, distributed network, ventral areas, dorsal areas, functional gradients, shape abstraction, visual architecture

title: Imagining material versus geometric properties of objects
summary: This study examines how the brain differentiates between imagining the material properties (such as texture or brightness) and geometric properties (such as shape or contour) of objects. Using fMRI, the authors found that imagining material properties activates regions related to ventral tactile and visual perception, while geometric properties involve more dorsal areas associated with spatial analysis. This evidence points to a functional separation in the mental representation of objects based on the type of attribute perceived or imagined
keywords: imagination of objects, material properties, geometric properties, fMRI, ventral visual cortex, dorsal visual cortex, mental representation, tactile perception, spatial analysis

title: Steady-state visually evoked potentials: paradigms and perspectives
authors: Vialatte, F.-B., Maurice, M., Dauwels, J. & Cichocki, A.
summary: This article provides a comprehensive review of steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs), a periodic neural response generated by rhythmic visual stimuli. The authors discuss the underlying neurophysiological mechanisms, optimal stimulation frequencies, and applications in cognitive neuroscience and brain-computer interfaces. It is highlighted that the frequency and intensity of the visual stimulus can modulate the amplitude and phase of the cortical response, providing information on neural synchronization and visual plasticity
keywords: steady-state evoked visual potentials, SSVEPs, neurophysiology, rhythmic stimulation, cognitive neuroscience, brain-computer interfaces, neural synchronization, visual plasticity

title: The steady-state visual evoked potential in vision research
summary: This review analyzes the use of steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs) in vision research. The authors discuss how different visual stimulus frequencies produce specific cortical responses and how these can be used to study perception, attention, and sensory integration. Practical applications in studies of cognition, development, and visual pathologies are also reviewed, highlighting the robustness and accuracy of SSVEPs for mapping neural activity related to rhythmic stimuli
keywords: steady-state evoked potentials, SSVEPs, vision research, perception, attention, sensory integration, cognition, visual development, visual pathologies, neural activity

title: Characteristics of steady-state and transient responses evoked by modulated light
summary: This classic study analyzes the brain's visual responses to modulated light stimuli, differentiating between transient and steady-state responses. Regan shows that SSVEP responses are highly dependent on stimulus frequency and that the amplitude and phase of the EEG signal vary according to light modulation. These findings provide the basis for understanding how the visual system encodes temporal information and how visual stimuli can be optimized to generate predictable cortical responses
keywords: evoked visual potentials, transient responses, steady-state responses, SSVEP, light modulation, stimulus frequency, temporal coding, visual system, EEG

title: Human EEG responses to 1–100 Hz flicker: resonance phenomena in visual cortex
summary: This study examines how the human brain responds to intermittent visual stimuli (flicker) in a range from 1 to 100 Hz, using EEG. Resonance phenomena are identified in the visual cortex, where certain frequencies generate amplified responses, indicating that the brain has optimal frequency bands for visual processing. These findings are fundamental to understanding neural synchronization, temporal stimulus processing, and the design of visual stimuli for research and neurotechnology applications
keywords: evoked visual potentials, EEG, flicker, cortical resonance, visual cortex, neural synchronization, temporal processing, neurotechnology, stimulus design

title: Presence of strong harmonics during visual entrainment
summary: This study investigates the generation of strong harmonics in the visual cortex during rhythmic visual entrainment. Using MEG, the authors show that periodic visual stimulation produces not only fundamental responses but also multiple harmonics, reflecting complex neural dynamics and the interaction between different cortical networks. The findings help to understand how the frequency and pattern of stimuli modulate neural synchronization and visual perception
keywords: visual entrainment, harmonics, MEG, visual cortex, neural dynamics, cortical networks, neural synchronization, visual perception

title: Optimal gamma-band entrainment of visual cortex
summary: This study explores how the human visual cortex responds to entrainment in the gamma band (~30–100 Hz) using neuroimaging techniques. The authors show that there is an optimal range of gamma frequencies that maximizes neural synchronization and improves the encoding of visual stimuli. Furthermore, they observe that this synchronization facilitates the integration of color, shape, and movement, suggesting applications for the design of visual stimuli that optimize perception and attention
keywords: visual entrainment, gamma band, visual cortex, neural synchronization, neuroimaging, stimulus encoding, sensory integration, visual perception, attention

title: Rod-driven frequency entrainment and resonance
summary: This study analyzes how rods (low-light-sensitive photoreceptors) contribute to cortical entrainment and resonance in response to periodic visual stimuli. Using EEG, the authors show that stimulation frequency modulates neuronal response depending on the rod-dominant pathway, highlighting differences between perception in low-light and high-light conditions. The findings provide key information for designing effective visual stimuli in environments with variable lighting and for understanding the contribution of the rod pathway to cortical synchronization
keywords: visual entrainment, rods, cortical resonance, EEG, rod-dominant pathway, visual perception, variable illumination, cortical synchronization

title: Attenuated fast SSVEPs during sleep
summary: This study investigates how steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs) are affected during sleep. Using EEG, the authors show that rapid responses to periodic visual stimuli are significantly attenuated compared to wakefulness, indicating a decrease in neural synchronization and cortical sensitivity during different sleep stages. These results help to understand how visual processing and cortical attention change in altered states of consciousness
keywords: SSVEPs, sleep, EEG, neural synchronization, cortical sensitivity, visual processing, cortical attention, altered states of consciousness

title: Visual stimulation under 4 Hz, not 10 Hz, generates distinct responses
summary: This study analyzes how different frequencies of visual stimulation affect cortical response as measured by EEG. The authors show that stimuli at 4 Hz generate distinctive responses compared to 10 Hz, highlighting that low frequency produces greater synchronization in certain visual areas. These findings suggest that the choice of stimulation frequency is crucial for manipulating cortical activity and designing optimized visual stimuli for perception and neuroaesthetics experiments
keywords: visual stimulation, low frequencies, EEG, cortical synchronization, visual perception, neuroaesthetics, stimulus design, cortical response

title: Critical flicker fusion frequency: a narrative review
summary: This narrative review analyzes the critical flicker fusion frequency (CFF), which is the speed at which an intermittent stimulus is perceived as constant. The authors discuss how factors such as luminance, color, age, and fatigue affect CFF, as well as its implications for visual perception, display design, and SSVEP studies. The paper also synthesizes findings on individual variability and the neural mechanisms that determine the temporal perception of visual stimuli
keywords: critical flicker fusion frequency, CFF, visual perception, luminance, color, age, fatigue, screen design, SSVEP, neural mechanisms

title: SSVEPs reveal crossmodal pitch–vision associations
summary: This study explores crossmodal associations between sound (pitch) and visual perception using steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs). The authors show that certain visual frequencies synchronize with specific tones, revealing multisensory integration in the visual and auditory cortex. The findings suggest that the brain integrates information from different sensory modalities to create coherent perceptual experiences, with implications for neuroaesthetics and the design of multisensory stimuli
keywords: SSVEPs, crossmodal associations, visual perception, auditory perception, multisensory integration, visual cortex, auditory cortex, perceptual experiences, neuroaesthetics, multisensory design

title: SSVEPs combined with behavioural tasks in perception research
summary: This study combines steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs) with behavioral tasks to investigate visual perception. The authors show that SSVEPs reflect not only cortical response to rhythmic stimuli, but also attention and performance in cognitive tasks. These findings underscore the usefulness of SSVEPs as a tool for linking neural activity to perceptual behavior and for designing experiments that explore the interaction between visual stimulus and behavioral response
keywords: SSVEPs, behavioral tasks, visual perception, attention, cognitive performance, neural activity, perceptual behavior, experimental design

title: Review of computational neuroaesthetics
summary: This review analyzes the emerging field of computational neuroaesthetics, which combines neuroscience, psychology, and computational modeling to understand how the brain responds to aesthetically meaningful stimuli. Methods for quantifying neural responses to visual properties such as color, shape, symmetry, and complexity are discussed, as well as machine learning techniques for predicting aesthetic preferences. The work highlights the importance of integrating empirical data with computational models to explore aesthetic perception in a systematic way
keywords: computational neuroaesthetics, neuroscience, psychology, computational modeling, neural responses, visual properties, machine learning, aesthetic preferences, aesthetic perception, data integration

title: A narrative scoping review of neuroaesthetics and visual perception
summary: This narrative review addresses neuroaesthetics and visual perception, exploring how different visual properties (color, shape, light) affect aesthetic experience and brain activity. It highlights neuroimaging studies that show the involvement of the visual cortex, reward-related areas, and frontal regions in aesthetic appreciation. The article also discusses methodological approaches and applications in visual design, art, and interactive environments
keywords: neuroaesthetics, visual perception, visual properties, aesthetic experience, brain activity, neuroimaging, visual cortex, reward areas, visual design, art

title: Shaping and reshaping the aesthetic brain: emerging perspectives
summary: This article reviews how aesthetic experience modifies brain activity and visual perception. The authors discuss how visual, musical, and artistic stimuli activate networks that include the visual cortex, reward areas, and frontal regions. In addition, they explore how repeated exposure and prior experience can “reconfigure” aesthetic perception and neural response, providing evidence for brain plasticity in artistic appreciation
keywords: aesthetic experience, brain activity, visual perception, visual cortex, reward areas, brain plasticity, artistic appreciation, neural networks, visual stimuli, perceptual reconfiguration

title: Neuroelectrical brain imaging on perception and appreciation of pictures
summary: This study uses electrical neuroimaging (EEG) techniques to investigate how the brain processes and appreciates visual images. The authors show that the perception of aesthetically pleasing images activates both the visual cortex and regions associated with reward, highlighting the interaction between sensory processing and emotional evaluation. The relationship between visual characteristics of images (color, shape, composition) and neural response is emphasized, offering relevant information for neuroaesthetics and visual design
keywords: electrical neuroimaging, EEG, visual perception, aesthetic appreciation, visual cortex, reward areas, sensory processing, emotional evaluation, visual characteristics, visual design

title: Decoding color and luminance from responses in human visual cortex
summary: This study investigates how the human visual cortex encodes color and luminance information using fMRI and multivoxel analysis. The authors show that activation patterns in visual areas, especially V1 and V4, allow for accurate decoding of perceived color and luminance levels. The findings highlight that visual perception does not depend solely on physical stimuli, but on distributed neural representations that integrate color and brightness information
keywords: visual cortex, color coding, luminance, fMRI, multivoxel analysis, visual areas, visual perception, neural representations, color integration, brightness

title: Color, motion, and attention in the human visual cortex
summary: This study explores how the human brain simultaneously processes color, motion, and attention in the visual cortex. Using fMRI, the authors show that different visual areas (such as V1, V2, V4, and MT) respond selectively to these attributes, while attention modulates the intensity and precision of activation. The results suggest that visual perception is the product of dynamic interactions between specific attribute processing and attention mechanisms, enabling an integrated representation of stimuli
keywords: visual cortex, color processing, motion processing, visual attention, fMRI, visual areas, dynamic interactions, visual perception, integrated representation, attention mechanisms

title: The contribution of area V4 to human color vision
summary: This study analyzes the role of the V4 area in color perception in humans. Using fMRI and lesion studies, the authors show that V4 is crucial for color discrimination and color constancy. Activation in V4 allows colors to be perceived stably despite changes in lighting, indicating that this region integrates color information and visual contexts to generate a coherent perceptual experience
keywords: V4 area, color perception, fMRI, color discrimination, color constancy, color integration, perceptual experience, visual context

title: Distributed neural systems for shape perception
summary: This study investigates how the brain perceives shapes using a distributed neural network that includes ventral and dorsal areas of the visual cortex. Using fMRI, the authors show that different regions encode different levels of shape information, from local features to global representations of objects. The integration of these signals enables efficient and robust shape recognition across variations in size, orientation, and texture, highlighting hierarchical and collaborative processing in visual perception
keywords: shape perception, distributed neural network, ventral visual cortex, dorsal visual cortex, fMRI, shape coding, object recognition, hierarchical processing, signal integration

title: Single-trial EEG analysis reveals burst structure during flicker stimulation
summary: This study uses EEG analysis in individual trials to examine the structure of neural bursts during intermittent visual stimulation (flicker). The authors show that the cortical response is not continuous, but rather organized into patterns of synchronized bursts that vary according to the frequency of the stimulus. These findings provide insight into the temporal dynamics of the visual cortex and how rhythmic stimuli modulate neural activity in single trials
keywords: EEG, single trial analysis, neural bursts, intermittent visual stimulation, flicker, temporal dynamics, visual cortex, neural modulation, synchronized patterns

title: Stimulus design affects harmonic content of SSVEP responses
summary: This study investigates how the design of visual stimuli influences the harmonic content of SSVEP responses. The authors show that variations in frequency, shape, contrast, and color of the stimulus generate different patterns of harmonics in the visual cortex, indicating that the neural response is sensitive to the properties of the stimulus. These findings are relevant for optimizing visual stimulation paradigms and understanding how stimulus structure modulates neural synchronization
keywords: stimulus design, harmonic content, SSVEP, visual cortex, stimulus frequency, stimulus shape, contrast, color, neural synchronization, visual stimulation paradigms

title: Critical perspectives on gamma-band visual entrainment
summary: Este artículo revisa críticamente los estudios sobre el entrainment visual en la banda gamma (~30–100 Hz). Los autores discuten las metodologías, inconsistencias y limitaciones en la interpretación de resultados, destacando cómo factores como la frecuencia, intensidad del estímulo y características individuales afectan la sincronización neuronal. Se propone un enfoque más riguroso para futuras investigaciones, considerando tanto la dinámica cortical como la percepción visual y la aplicabilidad en neurotecnología.
keywords: entrainment visual, banda gamma, sincronización neuronal, metodología, dinámica cortical, percepción visual, neurotecnología, limitaciones de estudio, frecuencia del estímulo, intensidad del estímulo

title: Color preference modulates activity in visual cortex
summary: Este estudio investiga cómo las preferencias de color de los individuos influyen en la actividad de la corteza visual. Usando fMRI, los autores muestran que los colores preferidos generan mayor activación en áreas visuales como V4, y se observa también implicación de regiones relacionadas con recompensa. Estos hallazgos sugieren que la percepción estética del color está modulada por factores subjetivos y emociones, integrando procesamiento visual y afectivo.
keywords: preferencia de color, corteza visual, fMRI, área V4, procesamiento visual, emociones, percepción estética, integración afectiva, activación cortical

title: A functional and perceptual signature of the human visual cortex
summary: Este estudio analiza las características funcionales y perceptuales de la corteza visual humana utilizando técnicas de fMRI y análisis multivoxel. Los autores muestran que distintas áreas visuales codifican atributos específicos como color, forma y textura, y que estos patrones de activación están estrechamente relacionados con la percepción consciente de los estímulos. Los resultados destacan la existencia de una “firma” funcional que refleja cómo la corteza visual organiza y representa la información sensorial para generar experiencias perceptuales coherentes.
keywords: corteza visual, fMRI, análisis multivoxel, codificación de atributos, percepción consciente, representación sensorial, experiencia perceptual, organización cortical

title: The role of shape and color in visual illusion and grouping
summary: Este estudio analiza cómo la forma y el color contribuyen a las ilusiones visuales y al agrupamiento perceptual. Los autores muestran que ciertos patrones de color y configuración de formas pueden inducir percepciones engañosas, afectando la segmentación y organización de objetos en la visión. Estos hallazgos destacan la importancia de la interacción entre atributos visuales en la percepción y ofrecen información útil para diseño gráfico, neuroestética y comprensión de los mecanismos de agrupamiento visual.
keywords: forma, color, ilusiones visuales, agrupamiento perceptual, segmentación de objetos, percepción visual, interacción de atributos, diseño gráfico, neuroestética, mecanismos de agrupamiento

title: The effects of temporal frequency on motion and shape perception
summary: Este estudio investiga cómo la frecuencia temporal de los estímulos visuales afecta la percepción del movimiento y la forma. Los autores muestran que frecuencias más altas facilitan la detección de movimiento, mientras que frecuencias más bajas mejoran la percepción de forma. Estos hallazgos sugieren que el cerebro ajusta el procesamiento visual según la dinámica temporal del estímulo, implicando mecanismos diferenciados para análisis de forma y movimiento.
keywords: frecuencia temporal, percepción del movimiento, percepción de la forma, procesamiento visual, estímulos visuales, mecanismos diferenciados, análisis visual, dinámica temporal

title: Specificity of flicker adaptation
summary: Este estudio examina la adaptación neuronal específica al parpadeo (flicker) visual. Los resultados muestran que la exposición repetida a estímulos intermitentes reduce la respuesta cortical, pero de manera selectiva según la frecuencia y características del flicker. Esto indica que la corteza visual adapta su sensibilidad a estímulos rítmicos específicos, lo que tiene implicaciones para comprender mecanismos de adaptación, percepción temporal y diseño de estímulos visuales en investigación neurofisiológica.
keywords: adaptación al parpadeo, flicker, respuesta cortical, corteza visual, sensibilidad neuronal, percepción temporal, mecanismos de adaptación, estímulos rítmicos, investigación neurofisiológica

title: Temporal impulse response functions for luminance and color
summary: Este estudio analiza cómo la corteza visual responde a cambios temporales en luminancia y color mediante funciones de respuesta al impulso temporal. Los autores muestran que la percepción de luminancia y color sigue diferentes perfiles temporales, indicando que existen mecanismos separados para procesar información de brillo y cromática. Estos hallazgos proporcionan información clave sobre el procesamiento temporal de estímulos visuales y la codificación neuronal de atributos visuales esenciales.
keywords: respuesta al impulso temporal, luminancia, color, corteza visual, procesamiento temporal, mecanismos separados, percepción visual, codificación neuronal, atributos visuales

title: Functional architecture for disparity and shape in macaque V4
summary: Este estudio investiga cómo el área V4 de macacos procesa información de disparidad y forma. Utilizando registros neuronales, los autores muestran que V4 contiene mapas funcionales especializados que codifican profundidad (disparidad) y características de forma de manera integrada. Estos hallazgos sugieren que V4 combina información espacial y de forma para apoyar la percepción tridimensional y la representación de objetos complejos, proporcionando un modelo de arquitectura visual jerárquica y distribuida.
keywords: área V4, disparidad, forma, macacos, registros neuronales, mapas funcionales, percepción tridimensional, representación de objetos, arquitectura visual, procesamiento integrado

title: Parallel, multi-stage processing of colors and shapes
summary: Este estudio analiza cómo el cerebro procesa colores y formas en paralelo y en múltiples etapas. Usando fMRI, los autores muestran que diferentes áreas de la corteza visual ventral procesan simultáneamente atributos cromáticos y geométricos, con integración posterior en niveles jerárquicos superiores. Esto sugiere un modelo de procesamiento visual distribuido y especializado, donde la percepción de objetos depende de la combinación de rutas paralelas que manejan color y forma de manera coordinada.
keywords: procesamiento paralelo, colores, formas, corteza visual ventral, fMRI, integración jerárquica, percepción de objetos, rutas paralelas, procesamiento visual distribuido

title: The processing of color and form: an overview
summary: Esta revisión ofrece una visión general de cómo el cerebro procesa color y forma. Los autores discuten hallazgos de neuroimagen, estudios de pacientes y experimentos de percepción, mostrando que color y forma son procesados en rutas parcialmente separadas dentro de la corteza visual, pero que se integran en etapas superiores para la percepción coherente de objetos. Se destacan aspectos funcionales de áreas como V1, V2 y V4, y cómo la interacción entre rutas contribuye a la percepción visual y la atención.
keywords: procesamiento del color, procesamiento de la forma, corteza visual, neuroimagen, percepción visual, integración de rutas, áreas visuales, atención visual

title: From simple cells to perception of shape and color
summary: Este estudio revisa cómo la información visual se transforma desde células simples en la corteza primaria hasta la percepción compleja de forma y color. Se discuten mecanismos de integración neuronal que permiten combinar información de contornos, orientación y cromaticidad, así como la interacción entre vías ventral y dorsal. Los hallazgos proporcionan un marco para entender cómo el cerebro construye representaciones perceptuales ricas a partir de señales sensoriales básicas.
keywords: células simples, percepción de la forma, percepción del color, corteza primaria, integración neuronal, vías ventral y dorsal, representaciones perceptuales, señales sensoriales

title: Cortical mechanisms of color vision
summary: Este artículo revisa los mecanismos corticales responsables de la percepción del color. Se analiza la función de áreas visuales como V1, V2 y V4 en la codificación de información cromática, la constancia de color y la discriminación de tonalidades. También se discuten modelos teóricos sobre cómo la corteza integra señales de diferentes tipos de conos y cómo la interacción entre rutas paralelas permite la percepción estable y precisa del color.
keywords: mecanismos corticales, percepción del color, corteza visual, áreas V1, V2, V4, codificación cromática, constancia de color, discriminación de tonalidades, integración de señales, rutas paralelas

title: Spatial frequency and flicker interactions in steady-state responses
authors: Norcia, A. M. & Tyler, C. W.
summary: Este estudio analiza cómo la frecuencia espacial y el parpadeo (flicker) interactúan para generar respuestas visuales en estado estable (SSVEPs). Los autores muestran que la amplitud y fase de las respuestas dependen de la combinación de frecuencia espacial y temporal del estímulo, indicando que la corteza visual procesa de manera integrada estas propiedades. Los hallazgos son fundamentales para comprender la codificación neuronal de estímulos complejos y optimizar paradigmas experimentales en neurofisiología visual.
keywords: frecuencia espacial, parpadeo, flicker, SSVEPs, corteza visual, codificación neuronal, estímulos complejos, neurofisiología visual, integración de propiedades, paradigmas experimentales

title: Impact of Color Psychology on Students’ Perception in Learning Spaces
summary: Este estudio examina cómo los colores de los espacios de aprendizaje afectan la percepción, el estado de ánimo y el rendimiento académico de los estudiantes. Se demuestra que los tonos cálidos aumentan la energía y la participación, mientras que los tonos fríos fomentan la concentración y la calma.
keywords: color psychology, learning spaces, mood, academic performance, environmental design

title: The influence of color on memory performance: A review
summary: Esta revisión analiza cómo diferentes colores afectan el rendimiento de la memoria. Los autores encuentran que ciertos colores, como el rojo, pueden mejorar la memoria a corto plazo, mientras que otros, como el azul, favorecen la memoria a largo plazo.
